name: Nicole Wein
content: Nicole Wein Nicole Wein nswein at umich dot edu Bio Students Teaching Service Other she/her Office: Beyster 3603 I am an assistant professor at the University of Michigan in the Theory of Computation Lab within the Computer Science and Engineering Division of the EECS Department. I did my PhD at MIT advised by Virginia Vassilevska Williams. Prospective PhD students: Unfortunately I am not looking for new PhD students this cycle. However, if you are interested in applying to University of Michigan's PhD program: Consider registering for the virtual Explore Grad Studies in CSE Workshop. If paying the application fee poses a challenge, you can apply for a waiver by Nov 16. My Research I am a theoretical computer scientist and my research involves graph algorithms and lower bounds including in the areas of distance-estimation algorithms, dynamic algorithms, parameterized algorithms, distributed algorithms, online algorithms, data structures, and fine-grained complexity. I am more broadly interested in algorithmic problems that are combinatorial in nature. Some questions that guide my research: How can algorithms cope with changing data? What information can algorithms extract from a graph in only (say) linear time? Can we understand the structure of shortest paths in graphs, especially directed graphs? Here's a short overview from 2023 of some of my research interests.
